title: What is up with my battery?

thread.text:
The battery on my Moto Z has been really poor lately. When off a battery mod, it uses about 1% a minute. On a turbo charger, it struggles to stay above 90%.
It finally got to 100% and I restarted the Z and the battery went to 6%. Restarted again and it jumped to 80%.
Is this battery toast?

Time for a new battery. Have you been using it constantly until it tells you to recharge it, or until it shuts off? (Letting any lithium battery fall below 40% is a bad idea, as far as the battry'e longevity goes.)

replies.text:
Honestly, I think I have let it get to 0 about 4 times since I bought the Z in October of 2016. I have had it on the Incipio Battery Mod since day one, so it normally stays around 80%.
Sounds like it needs to have the battery replaced, so I'll try that. Using a Moto G5 right now, so I can afford for my Z to be OOC for a few days.
Will report back post repair.

I've noticed my Moto Z battery has been very poor lately as well. I use it like you, always with a battery mod on keeping it at 80%. But now I'm starting to wonder if that didn't help speed up it's demise.
I remember a laptop I had that I kept plugged into A/C all the time. The battery in that died very quickly and I'm thinking maybe the battery mod does something similar to the Moto Z internal battery as well. The battery mod is constantly trickle charging the internal as it gets used, so the internal is basically always plugged in as long as the mod has juice.

thread.text: It's cactus. Replace it before it lets you down at a most inconvenient time...
Didn't think a battery replacement was easily available on these phones.
https://forums.lenovo.com/t5/Moto-Z/...filiate:bv0as6

Update. After changing to 100% with the phone off, I let it sit all day unplugged and powered off. This afternoon, I turned it on and the battery was 5%. 
Called local shop and they ordered a new battery. Should have it next week.

title: Moto Z Screen Cracked :(

thread.text:
Hello,
First time posting here. So I have a small hairline crack on my moto z. I looked on ebay and the screen with the digitizer is like 200 dollars, but there is also just the glass replacement for like 10 dollars. I think all I need is a glass replacement, but not sure. Has anyone repaired a cracked screen on a moto z before? And if so, what was the process like?
Thanks, I just hate living with an imperfect phone screen even if it is pretty small.

Try looking up a few YouTube videos on doing the replacement. Doing the screen with digitizer is difficult enough on most phones, but trying to replace just the glass is almost impossible. It is normally glued to the actual screen. Separating them looks very difficult. I was going to try replacing the glass on my daughter's S6E until I watched a few videos. I decided to take it to a repair shop that specializes in screen repair. It will cost about $220 for them to do it.

Motorola will replace the screen for $125 US per their chat support.
Chintakindi: The cost to replace the screen under Repair and Return program is - (Sub-Total: $125.00)
Robert: OK, thank you very much. Does the price change after the warranty expires?
Chintakindi: No Robert, the price will be same.

I know that stinks, but all things considered I've seen companies charge more. I would go with a tempered glass screen protector after you get it replaced. Sometimes that can take the brunt of the damage and can be easier and cheaper to replace.
Yeah $125 for a screen replacement done properly by the manufacturer is extremely reasonable. +1 for a tempered glass protector when you get it back.

Welcome to Android Central! 
First: I am sorry that your screen cracked! That is awful!
Are you under any kind of warranty? Also, how old is this device? 
A word of caution: if you've never repaired a phone screen before, I would recommend not doing so; or even showing it to a cellular repair shop and seeing if they can fix it for a decent price. If you have any kind of warranty, insurance, or coverage on your phone (ie, you're under a contract, for instance), taking the phone apart yourself will void all of that. 
Good luck finding a solution! I definitely get what you mean: a cracked screen, no matter how minimal, is frustrating! Plus, even smaller cracks can expand in time and that can damage the internal composition of your phone; so it's best to get your device looked at sooner rather than later - good for you for jumping on this now!
I cracked my tempered glass, but I thought Motorola had some type of shatterproof guarantee. I could be wrong though
Moto Z Force has the Shattershield, the Z does not.

replies.text: Some manufacturers have been touting their glass screens as shatter resistant, and offering a warranty on shatters. I'm not aware of Motorola offering this on the non-shattershield devices, but it'd be worth talking to a Moto rep about.

What about the Z play? 
Dropped mine yesterday and the tempered glass shattered. Now I think I can see a tiny tiny crack on the glass (screen looks and works perfectly)
As benjamminh said, the only 2 phones with Shattershield are the Droid Turbo 2 and the Moto Z Force. The Moto Z and Moto Z Play both have Gorilla Glass.

thread.text: Only the Z Force and the DT2 have the Shattershield screen in the Moto phones. Samsung Active line has something similar
Curious what height you guys dropped from and onto what surface? These are still Gorilla glass 3 (or 4?) and supposed to be pretty crack resilient as well.

Thought I had cracked my Z after a drop. Was investigating all the same things. Then realized only the Zagg glass protector was cracked. Used Zagg replacement policy and am back in business. Never again will I be without Zagg.

title: Motorola Call/Speakerphone Quality (and other stuff)

thread.text:
Motorola owners, 
Just looking for some feedback on Moto devices in general as I'm considering one for my next phone. One reason being cost - after reading the AC article today about "how much would you pay for a smartphone", I'm inspired. The beautiful thing about Android, there's so many choices out there and you don't have to spend $1,000 for a device. You don't HAVE to buy a Note ... or a Pixel ... there ARE other options! 
One thing I'm a stickler for, after 10 years of learning what I like and don't like, is call quality and a really clear sounding speakerphone function. It is a phone, after all, right? For the last several years call quality has been more of an afterthought - for me - in favor of flashy bells & whistles and gimmicky features. Honestly, while I'd still prefer a balance of call quality and features, I'd definitely put the priority on call quality. 
What are your thoughts on Moto devices in general? Where do they really excel? 
Thanks

It is true that call quality is taken for granted these days. While I am not a call quality connoisseur, I find Moto phones to have good and clear cellular call quality (I use Z2 Play).
What is also interesting, I find, is the Moto, at least my Z2 Play anyway, has a significantly better antenna quality compared to my "old" LG G6. There is a spot in my office building where it is difficult for most phones to get any signal reception, even wifi. My Z2 Play is probably one of the only 2 phones in the office (the other being the boss's S8+) to be able to receive any decent signal reception at all. This antenna quality may or may not have an impact on the cellular call quality you are looking for.
Good info - thanks 👍

title: Cant delet files in Adoptable Storage

thread.text:
I have my android MOTO Z for a while and it worked as adoptable storage. The thing is that when I try to delet image or video or whatever from the "adoptable Storage" folder, the system says it fails to erase.. So my SD disk is now full and I cant delete anything.
Any suggestions?

That's by design. Adopted storage means that you have converted the SD card into permanent storage for the phone, and you should not be trying to delete or add files to the SD card from another device.
See https://www.androidcentral.com/adoptable-storage
If you wanted to use the SD card for storage, you should have formatted it as portable storage, not internal storage.

I have really liked it, but I have had these problems with it: 1) I have had the "clear coat sloughing off on the edges" as well. 2) After about 10 months, the rubber nub of the bumper case finally broke off.....I am guessing that was caused by a combination of frequent use of that button, plus me putting it in and out of my jeans' pocket (likely) a thousand or two times over that 10 months (those rubber button cover *do* protrude from the bumper case some), and probably most importantly, 3) I had recently begun to suspect that having this bumper case on my smartphone was *degrading* both WiFi and cellular signal performance.....so yesterday I used the phone with the bumper case off (which made me nervous about dropping it, because the phone is VERY slippery), BUT the wireless performance *did* seem much better! The problem is, however, there really aren't many alternatives when it comes to bumper cases for these Moto Z line of smartphones

title: Random freezes/crashes

thread.text: Anyone else experiencing random lockups on there phone where the only remedy is to hold down on the power button until the start up(reboot) screen appears? This has happened to me on average about once a day now for the last week+.

replies.text:
A couple of questions:
1. How much free internal storage do you have?
2. Have you tried clearing cache in recovery?
3. Do you have a SD card installed? Do you use it as portable storage or internal memory?

I believe I have over 30%+ left of internal storage. 
I haven't tried cleaning the cache. How would I do that?
I do have a SD card installed. It is portable store/external. I didn't make it my internal memory.
Definitely appreciate the help. Thanks!
I'm guessing it sounds like a misbehaving app. If you can pinpoint an app that you installed right before it started happening, you could uninstall the app and see if that fixes it.

thread.text: I haven't experienced anything like that on my Z Force Droid. That sounds very frustrating. Have you installed any new apps right around the time this started?

You could try this to clear the app cache:
Open Settings > Storage > tap Internal shared storage > wait for all the numbers to load > tap Cached data > tap OK > wait for the numbers to re-calculate > turn phone Off

Here are the steps to clear the system cache:
Wipe cache partition:
With the phone powered off, press and hold the Volume Down button and the Power button at the same time until the device starts to turn on, let go of buttons.
Press the Volume Down button to highlight "Recovery mode"
Press the Power button to restart into Recovery mode.
You'll see an image of an Android robot with a red exclamation mark.
Holding the Power button, tap Volume Up once and then release the Power button.
Use the volume buttons to scroll to "wipe cache partition" and press the Power button to select it.
Select Ok or Yes to continue.
When finished, "Reboot system now" will be highlighted, press the Power button to select it
Yes. I am having lock ups may be once a week. Phone freezes and the only solution is hold down power button till it resets.
Yes I too am having this problem on Moto Z Force. For me seems to happen the most when I am listening to audio over Bluetooth. PocketCast, TuneIn Radio.

title: PSA: Keep the Style Shell on when you're not using any mods

thread.text:
Well, this was unfortunate.
I came back home wanting to check out what I missed on the Moto since switching to the Note8 as my daily driver.
Imagine my shock when I saw liquid all over the Motomod pins. I was very sure the table was very dry when I set it there, so I eventually traced the culprit to a leaking A/C.
Regardless, I noticed black marks around the pins. I initially thought they were just dirt marks and proceeded to try to wipe them. Sadly, they stayed on, and upon closer inspection, they were actually scorch marks, complete with tiny cracks.
Fortunately, the phone still works and it seemed that the Motomods also work, but the presence of the scorch marks was actually quite daunting, indicating that there may have been a short.
So my advice to anyone with any one of the Moto Z phones is to at least put a Style Shell or any cover. Sadly, neither Z2 models come with one.
GREAT advice! Or do as I did leave the battery mod on when not using any other mods.

Side note I found interesting. Due to the hours of Google Maps navigation use I have burn-in on my screen showing all the static buttons and panels on the navigation screen. Very visible. Not really a problem for me though.

When you say you "close out" the apps, do you mean hit the Home button, hit the Back button or swipe them off the "recently used" screen? (Only the back button or exit on the app's menu if it has one actually closes the app. hitting the Home button leaves the app running. But with 4GB of RAM you shouldn't have a problem.)
You might consider a factory data reset. Or you might have a rogue app or apps.
Is there any way to spit out a text based list of installed apps? I don't think I have anything out of the ordinary.
I hit the bottom right button on the screen that brings up a 3d tile view of the running apps. Right Swipe to close or Close All if I don't have a navigation running.

Start either backing out of apps, or using the "exit" or "quit" selection on the app's menu if it has one.
As for a list of installed apps, there may be an app that can do it, but the only way I've ever gotten close to that (I didn't produce a text list because I don't need one) is to back up everything using App Backup & Restore, then copying its whole folder to my PC. If you look at the contents of the folder in the PC, you'll see all your installed apps (and some that come with the phone). If you run a command window in that folder and type
dir > files.txt
You'll get a file named files.txt, with the full list of the files - which is a full list of your apps. (You could do it by plugging the phone into the computer, going to the folder there and running the command, but make sure you have a book to read.)

Would it be helpful to do that, or to stitch together a tall image of my Settings > Apps > All Apps, to post here? I'm just giving things a bit more time for more replies before likely doing a factory reset. 
In all reality is probably because I have it running, screen on, for pretty much the entire day, every day. Especially if I can't find any sketchy apps and if it continues after reset.

Does it overheat with you using it all day every day with the screen on and navigation running? Heat is bad for any phone. You can install an app to monitor battery heat if you don't have that already.
Not that I've noticed though I do have a vent aimed at the back of it on the dash mount. My crappy work Android I have to use for my job's app gets hot though.
How to restart my camera

replies.text: Close the camera app as usual, then hit the "square" on the bottom right of your phone which opens a display the most recent apps you've had open. On the top right hand corner of these as it's an "x". Tap that and the app will be completely closed. Or....you could just restart the phone

thread.text: My guess is that it's a rogue app slowing things down. I have no clue what it might be. But yeah, factory reset is probably what I would do if it were my phone.

I did the factory reset. Still gets sluggish around 6 hours or so now. Maybe constant delivery courier style work is too much for it. I deleted any app that I haven't used in a while.
Strange thing though. I do voice/spoken input for most things I do on the phone. Now when I hit the mic button it will engage for a split second, then stop. I have to tap it a second time to get it to start listening. 
Gboard is default keyboard. Google Voice Typing also set up.

title: Visible burn-in after 2 months?

thread.text:
Hi,
I bought Moto Z in June. Right now in August I just noticed burn in on-screen buttons. Got lighter stripe on the bottom and top of the screen, as those are usually black for notification bar and buttons. It's visible on white background but also while playing games, watching videos etc. Not super intense, but I did notice it when launching some full-screen app.
I would consider myself heavy user (maybe 3-4 hours daily average, to some degree replacing my broken laptop) but never expected a burn-in that fast. My brightness usually stays low.
Is this normal? I got this brand new off german Amazon for a very low price, but if that's AMOLED standard, then I 'll go for V20 from aliexpress and sell this thing. Sure, no real warranty and could get +30% price due to customs & VAT (randomly applied), bootloop issues could strike, but I think it's still better than this? Like, Hi-Fi audio, wide angle lens, removable battery, no burn-in...
Someone could say take better care of the phone, use it less, quickly turn my screen off, hide on-screen buttons - but then, why would I buy it? To have a pretty expensive piece of metal on my desk? It's supposed to do it's job, if AMOLED is so fragile maybe it shouldn't be used in pricey piece of electronics I buy for longer then a couple of months?

That is not normal, burn in does happen, but usually takes much longer. 
Personally never had it happen to me, but I've seen it in person numerous times.

Attached some pictures (white screen, blue screen, some content).
It's a bit easier to see in real life, I guess it's dynamic range thing, cameras won't reproduce slight differences well enough. I'll try contacting motorola about it and then probably Amazon.
It's the first time I saw this, and I would expect this to be more gradual, slow, over-time process. If you asked me 2 days ago if I have any burn in issues I would say there are none.
So... maybe it's some kind of display malfunction causing it to deteriorate quickly? Anyone ever heard of such a thing?

title: Frequent installation and removal

thread.text: Does frequent installation and removal of mods damage the mod/phone or cause undue wear and tear. I've been removing my battery mod a bit to show people and on occasion to slim the phone down.
I don't have a Moto, but mechanical and electrical connections wear. I would not think connections in something that small would be very robust. FWIW.
They are magnetic. The main concern is the pins

I would think that by the very nature of the mods they shouldn't be damaged or damage the phone. Wanted to hear from someone that has had the z for a while and used mods to see if my assumption is right
As with all electronics just be gentle

The magnets that hold the Mods in place should not wear out with removal and installation. The connector pins might over time, but if you pull the Mod straight off, as recommended, and don't let it slide around during removal I don't see those pins wearing out with normal use for a long time
Thanks everyone
Has anyone had any issues with the contacts failing over time?

All in all I gave up and decided to just go as is with the phone bare. I honestly don't care if the shell is worn/damaged. And I don't really plan on using more mods. Made sure the bluetooth was on, and that both devices were in pairing/detect mode.Rebooted in safe mode, and tried it there.Was not given the available option to force stop or clear cache in the setup --> app menuRemoved any apps that I thought might be interferingChecked if desired devices were able to pair (verified by connecting to other devices with no issue)Full factory reset before trying it again

title: Using z with no mods

thread.text: Did anyone purchase the z with the intention of using it sans mods? I don't really have a need for any of the add ons but I keep feeling like that's the point of the phone and I'm missing out by not using them. I really got the phone for the near stock experience with some key enhancements. And the slimness.

My whole intention of buying a Z Force and Z Play for the wife, was to use Moto Mods. We own a JBL Soundboost each, we each have a Battery Mod, extra style shells, and she has the Hassleblad Mod. Not saying that you have to have the Mods to enjoy the phone, it's a great phone without the Mods. But for us, we wanted the added functionality that the Moto Mods bring to the phone.

I've tried the battery mod. I just can't justify $80 for something that I can find cheaper and with more capacity that he whole family (all apple users) can consume. It's cool but I have chargers at home, work, in the car, and a tiny external battery for the emergency gotta get by moments. Plus a 20k mAh pack for long trips. 
The soundboost sounds cool...cricket...but again o have a BT speaker already. And no need to leave my phone sitting out for it to work. I can walk around using my phone while playing tunes. 
I'm not bagging on the mods. They are the best implementation of a modular design this far. But I just don't have the use for them. And I feel like my phone is incomplete without something on the back.

I added the Moto Black leather style shell to my Moto Z Force and it's awesome. When I'm using a style shell, I protect the phone with the Verizon bumper. I bet a thin Z would look and feel awesome with the leather style shell.
I looked into getting the new style shell that adds wireless charging but it's out of stock. Might have to just get one from last year
I bought my z with the JBL speakers and the Hasselblad camera mod,I'm only missing the batterymod

The reason I'd get a style shell is only to make the phone look complete....and to even out the camera hump. But now that I really look at the back of my phone with the gold pins and metal finish (cards on the table I have a Z2 play but the forum for this phone has no participation) it kind of looks like something out of star trek.
It should have came with the dark wood style shell in the box?

My Z Force did, and so did my wife's original Z Play

title: Update removed shift key from keyboard

thread.text: I got the latest update for my Moto Z Droid phone and now the shift key doesn't appear on the keyboard. As I need to type in my password to unlock the phone, and my password contains a capital letter, I'm stuck! Help!

Welcome to the forums. Yeah, there are some reports about Gboard missing the swift key and the space bar after the update. There's an easy fix, but I'm not sure if it will work from the lock screen. Try this. From the keyboard, long press the 'comma' key, slide to cog/ settings icon, tap on 'Gboard keyboard settings', 'preferences' and switch 'numbers row' ON. Tell us how it goes.
Also, if you can't access the settings from the comma key, tap on the little arrow top left of the keyboard and then the cog/settings icon.
I can't get to the settings - there is no arrow at the top left. I just have the qwerty keyboard in lower case and numbers at the top.

replies.text: Thanks for registering. Yeah, I wasn't sure if it would work on the lock screen. Have you already tried booting in safe mode? Worth a try. Do you have any other keyboard installed in your phone?

thread.text: I moved your thread to the Moto Z forum where it'll be easier getting feedback from other owners.

I don't know if this will help at all, but I had a problem with the Shift Key not working when I had a USB keyboard plugged into my Android phone and I found a solution. Maybe the solution I found for my problem will fix your problem as well. If not, I do apologize.
I have a Samsung Galaxy S5 Android phone. I purchased a USB external physical keyboard that can connect with my Windows computers and my Android devices (via micro USB). The keyboard worked fine when I plugged it into my Windows computers. The keyboard worked pretty well Android phone, except for the fact that the Shift Key didn't do anything when I held it down and pressed other keys (to capitalize letters, type symbols found above the number keys, etc.). I tried a lot of stuff to get the Shift Key to work on my USB keyboard when I had it plugged into my phone. I couldn't get the Shift Key to work when I used the stock Google/Android keyboard app, the Samsung Keyboard app, or the SwiftKey Keyboard app. After a lot of trial and error with apps and settings (and a lot of frustration), I FINALLY came across an app that DOES solve the Shift key problem: The "Go Keyboard" app on the Google Play app store.
After I installed this app and set it as the default keyboard app on my Android phone (Samsung Galaxy S5), the Shift key worked just fine when I used it while it was plugged into my Android phone (allowing me to capitalize letters and type symbols above the number keys).
I hope this works for you, too!

title: How do you turn off the profanity filter in the moto z?

thread.text: There is no voice setting link as was present on my previous droid (which was a turbo 2). Also, how do you get rid of the picture icons when you are texting a word and it throws in the icon instead?
Mod Note: Thread moved for better visibility.

Welcome to the forums. You are using Gboard (Google keyboard), right?. Try this. Open the keyboard, long press the 'comma' key, slide to the settings/cog icon and select 'Gboard keyboard settings'. Now you need to change a couple of things here:
- Preferences. Enable 'voice input key'.
- Text correction. Disable 'block offensive words' and 'show emoji suggestions'.
- Voice typing. Disable 'block offensive words' and set your preferences.
Tell us how it goes.

title: Why isn't the Moto Z updated out of the box?

thread.text:
Hello All,
The is part telling you about an awesome deal and part gripe.
I've been looking for a new phone to upgrade from my Moto X play over the last few weeks knowing I couldn't afford a flag ship it was going to be either Moto G5 Plus or maybe the upcoming Moto X? I did look at other manufacturers but had a bad experience with a Chinese phone earlier in the year so wanted to stick with what I knew. Anyway there are some incredible deals on the original Moto Z at the moment!! If anyone's after a bargain I'd definitely recommend having a browse on the Moto website I'm in the UK I'm sure there are similar deals elsewhere. I paid £299 and got a free style shell, I would have also got a free JBL mod but they'd ran out.
So there's the deal now for the gripe.
Why don't phone manufacturers sell phones already updated with the latest software released for that phone!!! I understand if you buy from a carrier they could have had it for a while in stock but directly from the manufacturer it should be up to date. I've just received my Moto Z and from what I can tell it came with the software it was originally released with and I'm currently going through the update process I've been at it for nearly three hours with all the other setups and about 5 software updates so far it's some task setting up a new phone.

Congratulations on your Moto Z 
Enjoy it! 
You may find that the Moto Z you got is part of old stock, that's why it has the older software and has to he updated. It may have been sitting for a very long time between when it was built to when you got it.

title: Why is my phone so hot?

thread.text:
So I bought the Moto Z a few days ago. It keeps getting really hot, even if i'm not doing anything especially heavy. For example, if I'm browsing the web, sending some e-mails and sending some texts, it gets really hot after about 10 minutes. 
I got an app to measure the battery temperature, and it can rise to 38 or 39 degrees Celsius pretty easily (100 or 102 in fahrenheit).
Could a factory reset help this?

Welcome to the forums. Before a factory reset there are a couple of things worth trying. First check out regularly your battery stats and see if there's any app/process using a very high percentage.
Also, does this happen while on WiFi, mobile data or both? How's your cell signal?

Thanks for replying. This happens everytime, on WiFi, on mobile data, or when I have good reception.
I did check the battery usage, and no app seemed suspicious. The screen is using most of the battery, around 20 percent.
I posted this question 9 minutes ago, proceeded to use my phone to answer some texts and browse the web. When o started the battery was at 32 degrees, it now is at 39.

Hey Daniel, thanks for registering! Did you receive a system update after buying the phone? I would start for some basic troubleshooting before considering the factory reset, or some hardware problem.
Clear cached data in your storage settings and then wipe the cache partition from recovery. These are Motorola instructions for the Z Play.https://mobilesupport.lenovo.com/us/...ution/MS113289

Yes, it did several (maybe 5) updates after I purchased it, including the big upgrade from marshmallow to nougat.
I have wiped the cache several times, but will do it from recovery and get back to you. Thanks for taking the time.
But do you think that this rise in temperature is something abnormal? It has now gone to 40 degrees ( 104 Fahrenheit)

Yeah, I think that's a bit too hot for just basic usage. Have you noticed the same problem since day one or did it start after any of those updates?
I'll move your thread to the Moto Z forum where it'll be easier getting feedback from other owners.

Ok, so I just wipes the cache partition as you instructed. I then waited for the phone too cool down back to 32 degrees Celsius, as before, and have been using the phone for nine minutes. The temperature app says it is now at 38 degrees. During this time I opened a news app and open one article, browsed Google chrome, wrote one SMS, and open my email to check if something new was there.
I would say it's pretty much the same as before...
Oh, regarding updates, it was the first thing I did when I got the phone, so I never really used it without the nougat update...

Ok, so I just wipes the cache partition as you instructed. I then waited for the phone too cool down back to 32 degrees Celsius, as before, and have been using the phone for nine minutes. The temperature app says it is now at 38 degrees. During this time I opened a news app and open one article, browsed Google chrome, wrote one SMS, and open my email to check if something new was there.
I would say it's pretty much the same as before...
What's the temperature of the room where you're using it? Not that it should cause it to go this high under little use though.

I would troubleshoot this backwards. Turn off everything that you have running, like location, bluetooth, nfc, etc. Then turn them back on one at a time and see if any of them are causing the heating. For me, location on High Accuracy seems to heat my phone up.
if nothing there it could be an app that's running in the background and misbehaving. See which apps you have that run in the background and do the same thing shutting them down and running them one at a time.

It is pretty hot where I am (Portugal). I don't know the exact temperature, because I am indoors, that's why I let it cool down for half an hour before starting to use it (it was 32 degrees at that time). I have since done a factory reset, and it gets just as hot. Sometimes it reached 40 degrees.
However, I must say that I later compared it to a galaxy s7. It started at 33 degrees, and about 10 minutes later was at 37, while my Moto Z was at 38, wich is pretty much the same. I'm guessing that it might be mostly due to materials used and thinness that makes it feel hotter, given the s7 was pretty much at the same temperature.

I have since done a factory reset, so i'm guessing troubleshooting it backwards wouldn't make much of a difference. Like I said on a previous comment, my girfriend's s7 got just as hot yesterday with the same type of usage, but it wasn't as warm to the touch.
Maybe it has something to do with the materials...
How hot does your Moto Z get?

Hard to say because I always keep a battery mod on it so I can never really feel if and when it gets warm. I don't believe it does though, maybe on occasion. I know when I charged it wirelessly thought the battery mod the mod was quite warm while charging.

title: how do I maximize wifi speed

thread.text:
I just got a gigabit connection, and my 2x2 mimo laptop is able to get close to 600mbps down and up on wifi, but my phone struggles to even pass 200 (with a link speed of 867). What are the maximum that you guys are seeing, and do you have an tips or settings to achieve that? My sisters' iPhone is able to get over 500mbps down, so my Moto Z should be able to as well.
Even my old LG G4 which has a link speed of 433 can download 270+ with no sweat.

My iPhone 6 plus does 100Mbps on 5ghz wifi, and my s8+ does 165Mbs .
On a 200/20 line. Wired PC has no problem downloading 200Mbps.
Once did 178Mbps down on my T-Mobile bundle, but that was in a quiet area. Probably an antenna close by also.

There are a lot of variables involved, especially when it comes to WiFi. Wireless connectivity just cannot be looked at in the same way as wired connectivity. Wireless signal strength can vary because of dozens of reasons that are affected by any number of situations -- coverage range of your router's wireless signal, channel interference, noise floor, latency issues, plus keep in mind the antenna inside your phone is only a short wire running along the inside. I wouldn't focus too much on disparity of numbers between all your different gadgets and things, as WiFi itself is such a big variable. Your Mbps numbers all look to be pretty healthy as is. Another thing to take into consideration is if you live in a household where multiple residents will be watching their own hi-res video streams, depending on the time of day the available bandwidth numbers will be bouncing all over the place.

thread.text: Wireless Charging-only Moto Mods are coming soon.
Sounds like fun to me

I ended up buying the Z Play Droid a few weeks ago. So far I really like the phone. The battery life is amazing. I miss the smaller size of the Turbo, but everything else about the Z Play I like better.

I just got the Z Play, as a replacement for the Galaxy S6 I killed. I could have got the Z for not much more money, but my instincts were for the Z Play and I'm happy with that for now. 
The battery is incredible, particularly after the poor battery life on the S6. I would bet it's not just battery capacity but the problem of a 1440p screen though. I thought I might feel the loss of the resolution, but the Z Play's 1080p screen is pretty nice: no problems there. (Sidenote - I don't really trust wireless charging. I've had it on phones in the past, and it makes your phone hot. It's not a dangerous temperature on paper, but I don't like the idea of slowly weakening my phone over time like that, and for what? Slow, inefficient charging. Better to have enough charge to get through the day so that wireless is never a requirement.)
Camera isn't as good as the Z. It's passable, but a step down from my old S6. 
Build quality is great on the Z Play too imo, but you will need a case (glass is not shatterproof). 
CPU/GPU is behind the Z but not in ways that become apparent to me. I use a lot of apps, but not games. I hear it's games that show the difference between the two. Again, the lower spec chips are to the Z Play's advantage, helping it to use less power.
The Z Play is a very heavy phone. If that's an issue, you might prefer the option of the Z + mod. 
For me, the Z Play was the one. We just had that news about the Z2 range that's about to appear, so I'm likely to trade up to one of the Z2 models once they arrive, or take a Z or Z Force for the better camera if that's more cost-effective.

K

replies.text:
It's a funny bug affecting some Moto devices after the update. You could try a couple of things in settings - language & input - Gboard.
- In 'Preferences' enable the 'number row' and see if you get back those missing keys.
- In 'Theme' select a different one and make sure that 'Key borders' is off.

thread.text: First thing I would try is restarting your phone. If that doesn't work, and if your using Gboard (or really whatever keyboard app you're using), disable it and then​ enable it again.

Thanks for all your suggestions. What worked best was to reinstall the default keyboard.
It was a bit hairy, as I actually deleted the keyboard app; and ended up in a bit of a fix.
I was able to re-navigate to Google Play, found the app in the list, and reinstalled it.
That worked...

Thank you for your response, i got it to work on the first try. I was having the same issue as OP, missing space bar except for on numeric pad. Heres what I did:
1. Language & Input
2. Virtual Keyboard
2. Gboard
4. Preferences
5. Switch Number Row on.
Bam, it worked! Fixed!
Thank you!

replies.text: Glad it helped! Thank you for registering and giving us your feedback. It'll be very helpful for other users with a similar problem. Did you also try changing the theme and disabling the numbers row?

title: Why is my battery life getting worse and worse? Please help!

thread.text:
For the past month or so the battery life of Moto Z Droid has become horrible.
I have to charge it at least twice a day because it dies so quickly. 
This is with moderate use because I am in school most of the day.
It keeps saying the battery is being charged by a USB, but it never is. I always use AC charging.
I took multiple pictures so maybe they can explain more and better than I can.

Welcome to Android Central! Charge up to 100%, then let it drain to 20-30% with normal usage, without charging in between. Then show us: 
1. The main Settings>Battery screen.
2. The fullscreen battery graph screen (which shows Awake time and Cell Signal Strength).
3. The Screen category (to see total Screen On time).
4. The Cell Standby category, if present (to see Time Without Signal). http://forums.androidcentral.com/gen...d-central.html 
You might have to install a 3rd party battery monitor, like GSam Battery Monitor, to get the Cell Signal Strength graph.
If the battery charges up very slowly (while it's telling you it's charging via USB), then there might be a problem with your charger or the port. Does it charge up a lot more slowly? Have you already tried different charging cables/plugs?

Yes it charges extremely slowly and I have tried multiple different cords, yet they all give the same outcome.
My actual Motorola charger died or broke some how over a month ago. I've been using a Samsung charger ever since. Could this be a problem?
The guy at the store said it will be fine because their ports are the same.
I will do what you recommended about the battery from 100% to 20% tomorrow. I messed it up today by charging it in between by accident.
Are you saying that you've tried different cables, but always the same Samsung plug? Samsung chargers can sometimes be a little funky. Can you borrow any other charging plug?

I've tried all of those different plugs
I'm currently using the Samsung one, with the cord that's on the black box
Go to your local Verizon store and ask if you can test an original Moto charger and cable. If the same thing happens, then we can exclude that as the issue.
okay I will go to the Verizon store either tonight or tomorrow, here are the screenshots you asked for (at least I think they are lol)

title: Moto Z Droid memory upgrade

thread.text: Just purchased a Moto Z Droid with 32GB CD Card. I want to upgrade to a 128GB CD Card but the memory is set to "internal shared"(or adaptive). Can I replace the CD Card and change to "portable" memory without starting from scratch? What would be the proper procedure for this change? I am concerned that I will lose my new applications and the associated data.
Memory = RAM, you're talking about storage. Anyway, I'm pretty sure the SD card has to be reformatted to be changed from adaptive to external storage, or vice versa.

Just copy out the data you want saved to your computer and then replace the card and copy back the data to the new card. You may lose some applications depending on where they were written (internal storage or SD card), but you can just re-download them again from Google Play store.
Make sure to format the new card as portable storage.

title: How do you restart the phone on a brand new Moto Z?

thread.text: When trying to test out new phone, pressed camera icon and received error message, "restart camera" and I tried cutting phone off and back on again and again same error message. We tried the help section of the phone and did the testing and nothing works. When I used front facing camera it shows the image but not able to take picture. Help!

replies.text: You could go into settings-apps-camera and disable it. Then reboot your phone and go in and enable it and see if this clears up the issue.
What was the outcome of this?

thread.text:
Welcome to Android Central! To power off the phone, press and hold Power for about a second to bring up the Power menu. There should be a Power Off option, and possibly a Restart option.
You can try booting into Safe Mode to see if the camera works then: https://motorola-global-portal.custh...p/30,6720,9833. If it does, then something you installed is causing the problem -- uninstall apps one by one until the problem goes away.

thread.text: SanDisk 128gb card.

Welcome to Android Central! Adoptable Storage means the card gets incorporated into the device's Internal Storage. This allows you to expand the number of apps you can install. It also requires a fast-enough card, so if the card is too slow, the system will warn you that performance might be hindered. The speed of the card doesn't matter as much for Portable Storage (which is the conventional external SD card storage mode).

title: Frustrating Bluetooth Issue

thread.text:
I have a new BT issue that's driving me nuts. It has suddenly developed and seems to have occurred since the January security patch (although I can't be sure it wasn't slightly after). 
My Moto Z had no problem connecting to my car audio (stock 2016 BMW) over BT giving me metadata and track control, etc. I used the phone based Android Auto app to automatically launch on BT connect and then select my playback source (Spotify, PlayerFM, Tune In, etc) from the phone. All worked fine both under MM and with Nougat. Now, it connects and starts AA on the phone, but when I start playback I get no sound and no metadata. If I reboot the phone and then stop my car and restart it, it works fine for a few hours and then the same problem crops up. 
Any thoughts?

I think I might have solved it ... fingers crossed. Deleted the car from my phone and the phone from my car, rebooted the phone into safe mode and then added it back in and rebooted the phone. Five hours later, it worked fine.

title: Should I buy the Moto Z?

thread.text:
I'm getting a good deal on a new moto z for less than $400 Canadian. Should I buy this phone? Not a big fan of android. Had many android phones before but ended up going back to windows mobile.
How good is the voice assistance on moto z? That's one feature if it works well will tempt me to get this phone. Does ok google work all the time even when the phone is locked? Im on the road a lot so this is quite important to me. 
Any input from moto z users would be appreciated.

If you get the Moto Mod car mount it will always launch drive mode, and allow OK Google to launch apps and do pretty much everything hands-free. I am a big fan of WM10, but navigation is what moved me over RIP Lumia 950. I went with the Moto Z play unlocked for the 2 day battery life, but the Z is thin and pretty, was tempted by it before pulling the trigger on the Z Play. Anyways let me know if you have questions!

replies.text:
Thanks for your feedback. Where did you get the moto mod car mount? How well it responds to ok google voice command? When id the dtek60 even in drive mode the ok google voice didnt always work when the display is off. With Lumia 950 it almost never responds to voice command when the screen is off. In general how are you liking the phone? Anything I should be aware of before buying it?
Sent from mTalk

thread.text:
I went to a local Verizon store to get the moto mod mount, as it is only available online (Motorola) or in Verizon stores (dang exclusives). It responds much better then the L950 did using the same Bluetooth and car. The thing the mount does is allows the screen to always stay on, and it has a built in 15W USB C port and audio jack so it allows me to just pop off my wood back and boom drive mode enabled Bluetooth going and charging. This leaves a pretty slick Android Auto interface to play with or use "OK Google" to navigate also Amazon music, Pandora, and many others have app support for Android auto so their interface gets the nice large Android auto experience. 
All in all I really enjoy the phone again I went with the Moto Z Play, not the Z (as I wanted 2-3 day battery life) it performs much quicker then my L950 and actually doesn't lose GPS signal while in Nav mode. Only thing I would say is get a Nylon or Leather moto back if you don't like the wood look, as the glass is a fingerprint magnet and not sure it is Gorilla glass (think iPhone 4).
Hope this helps if you need pic or something let me know!

title: Charging recognition malfunctions until restart?

thread.text: I purchased my MOTO Z Force near launch and it's been fantastic. After the update last week though, a peculiar issue arises, twice so far. Sometimes when I plug it in to charge it's not recognized and refuses, but upon restart it is fine. The only chargers I use are the stock turbo power, my Ventev type C 4Amp charger and my 10000 mAh Anker portable power cell with Qualcomm 2.0. i tried all 3 when the problem arises. Anyone experiencing this or is there any investigation? Thanks.

Haven't heard of this yet. I haven't experienced any issues. 
As much of a pain as it is, if the issue continues I would consider a factory reset and see if that solves it. 
Maybe try cleaning the cache first though.
So you have a case, or anything that might obstruct the cable from fully seating?
I do, but it's the turtle armor case, has great clearing for the port. No issues there.

It's been a couple months now and this still occurs at least once every five plugins. It doesn't make much sense to me since I used a variety of cables, chargers, and my phone has had no damage really. The charging does not suffer when it's actually recognized but the recognition remains an issue. Again, not devastating to my daily use that I would need a refurbished one but annoying. Anyone experiencing this?
I'm not experiencing this on my Moto Z Force Droid.

Ry, I know you pay attention to what cables and chargers you use. But I will share an experience I had couple weeks ago on vacation. 
Had a usb hub charging block from Tronsmart. Great charging block and can charge 5 things at once. 
1 of the ports is usb 3. I wasn't paying attention and plugged in a Turbo. The cable got so hot I could barely hold the phone.
It happened within about 10 seconds and didn't do and damage to my phone. I think the cable just failed or wasn't rated for it. Phone worked fine and never had and issues. Cable was fried. 
I have been very careful about how I charge, and what equipment I use, but still made a mistake. Glad it was only a cable I lost. I won't turbo charge my devices.
I can't believe, no matter what anyone says, that rapid charging all the time is safe for the battery. I am amazed how hot devices get with it. I just bought a cheap G4 and it turbo charges. It got up to 2500 ma using Ampere. It also went over 115°. It was too hot to hold. I let it charge from 30% to 45% that way. Yes it's fast but repeated heating like that cannot be good for battery life. 
Just thought I would share this in case someone reads it and is reminded to pay attention to what they plug in to.

replies.text: Looks like Tronsmart isn't doing so hot in reviews. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets...f_TX8/pubhtml#

title: Facebook and Twitter icons not showing notifications

thread.text:
Hi,
I recently acquired the Moto Z (switched from Samsung Galaxy S7) and have a problem with my Facebook and Twitter icons/badges not showing the number of new notifications. I have the same version of the Facebook app on the S7 as well as my Asus Tablet and they both show notifications. Any ideas?
Thanks.

Yes, the Moto launcher doesn't show icon badges for third party apps like Facebook and Twitter. Standard Android doesn't support icon badges at all. If you want/need that, I suggest installing the third party launcher Nova Prime and their TeslaUnread plugin, which can show badges on these icons.[edit] I should add that standard Android through Marshmallow does not support icon badging. The latest version of Nougat and the launcher of the Google Pixel is, I believe, just starting to show icon badges.

Thanks for the reply. Do the Samsung Galaxy and Asus tablet use non-standard Android launchers then? 
BTW, I am running Android Version 7.0. Isn't that Nougat? What do you mean by Google Pixel? Do I have to do something to get it?

replies.text: Yep. Well, I'm not sure about Asus tables, but Samsung is definitely a customized version.The latest Nougat is Version 7.1, which is running only on Google Pixel and Nexus phones. Not on the Moto Z, yet. Sorry if I wasn't clear in my reply. Sometimes I assume that people know what I am talking about when I shouldn't assume so.

thread.text: Never mind. I just found out that Google Pixel is a phone.

Everyone, even Google, uses a custom launcher. 
Google Now Launcher is the AOSP launcher with Google Now integration to the left.
Pixel Launcher isn't the AOSP launcher. 
Moto Zs use a modified version of the AOSP launcher with badges for calls and texts and I think support for landscape and portrait orientation.

replies.text: To clarify, I wasn't talking about the launcher. Until Nougat 7.1 (apparently), there was no API in AOSP Android that supported icon badges. The home screen icons had no programmable way to overwrite icons on home screens or the app drawer. Custom launchers used by Samsung and Motorola (and other companies) have been using custom methods to provide these badges. Apparently 7.1 has added an API for this, or so I have read, even though the Pixel launcher doesn't show them itself.

thread.text: ASUS's ZenUI does have the unread count badge feature as well.
Okay. Bottom line, do I need to download a custom launcher such as Nova Prime if I want to receive the notification badges for Facebook and Twitter?

replies.text: Yes.
Thanks everyone!

thread.text: And if you install Nova Prime, you also need to install TeslaUnread (which is a very small app).

replies.text: Thanks everyone!

thread.text: Yes bottom line, install from Google Play store, Nova Plus launcher and Tesla badge plugin, it will work perfectly. I am using on an Axon 7 wih 6.01 android installed.

replies.text: Thanks everyone!

thread.text: In the Z line, Force camera is the best, with a decent gap to the Z Play, and a smaller gap to the regular Z. Honestly unless someone is in love with the Z form factor I'd either get the Force or Play.
Is the camera differences a hardware or software difference?

replies.text: Hardware.

thread.text: Due to the extra depth you have in the force?

replies.text: http://www.anandtech.com/show/10493/...droid-review/5

The Z Force has an entirely different camera package.
The Moto Z uses a 1/3" Sony Exmor IMX214 with a 13MP resolution and an f/1.8 aperture with contrast-detection autofocus assisted with a laser-based autofocus system. The Moto Z Force uses a larger 1/2.4" Sony Exmor IMX338 with a 21MP resolution with the same f/1.8 aperture and not only has contrast + laser autofocus but also adds phase-detection autofocus.
Because the actual sensor on the ZF is larger, the actual lens itself is also larger, allowing slightly more light, and the higher resolution does help make noise a little finer.

title: The ONE thing I miss from my 1st gen. Moto X. Why??

thread.text:
Hi all, I'll keep it brief. I've had a 1st gen Moto X on Republic Wireless since... well since the first day we were able to get a Moto X from Republic Wireless, whenever that was. Loved, loved that phone. Had a bamboo back on it, and the Moto Voice feature... It was something I thought was kind of gimmicky at first, but now I cannot, will not live without it. 
Anyway that phone is ancient by technology standards, but I just replaced it a couple of weeks ago with a Moto Z. So far, I'm not that impressed. I have some minor gripes I'm sure I'll get used to/get over, but there is one thing I cannot get past. On my Moto X, I could ask it "What's up?" and it would read my notifications to me. Very handy, if, say, I'm in the shower and hear a text or Facebook Message come in. I just shout out "Ok Google now, what's up?" and it reads my new messages to me, or at least who they're from (depending on how the particular messaging app handles notifications).
So, is it just me, or is this feature completely absent from the Moto Z? I ask it "what's up," and it does nothing. I've asked it "read me my notifications," doesn't work. Am I missing something? Or is this feature just gone? If so, WHY?!?

replies.text: As Google Voice Search got smarter, Moto Voice got phased out, even if it didn't match every feature.

thread.text: I'm able to ask Google to read my messages to me on my Moto Z and it will read my unread texts. I haven't tried anything else.

Did you open the Moto app and set up Moto Voice? On the original Moto X, that was done in settings / touchless controls. Now there is a separate Moto app for Moto Display, Moto Voice, Moto Actions (hands free voice control when you are driving or at a specific location), etc. See http://phandroid.com/2016/07/29/moto...ce-droid-tips/

title: My Moto Z Community Review

thread.text:
Yeah, this took longer than it should’ve been, but after over a month of having it as my daily driver, I’m ready to give my full thoughts on this.DESIGN AND BUILDIt’s definitely a polarizing thing. The Moto Z is really thin and has a design language that’s drastically different from the Moto X.Personally, I think the back looks pretty nice and rather “techy” looking, with a glass + metal back along with the pins for the MotoMod system and a rather large camera hump that resembles the face of a Moto 360.But the front on my White/Gold model looks pretty goofy. My thoughts haven’t really changed since the launch of the device at Lenovo TechWorld ’16. The front of the device definitely looks kinda goofy, especially on the chin with the square fingerprint sensor and the rather-large circles for the IR sensors used to activate Moto Display. The Black/Lunar Gray model looks much more understated and sleek IMHO, but a DBrand Hyperblack Titanium skin is going on the front.It’s also thin. REALLY THIN. At 5.2mm, it’s the thinnest flagship smartphone around. But none of that matters to me. Without the case and included style shell, the phone just feels too darn thin, as if it’s a really fragile piece of equipment. The included bumper and style shell helps “beef” up the device a bit, making it easier for me to handle, but the Incipio OffGRID will be an almost-permanent addition to mind not just for the significant increase in thickness but also for its extended battery.But it does really feel solid. The phone feels quite well-put together and does feel like it’s stronger than what its thin profile would suggest. Buttons are also very clicky, offering excellent tactile feedback, but they’re very small and evenly spaced. Despite having an aggressive texture on the power button, I found myself mispressing either the lock or volume-down button at times. I preferred the layout on my old Note 7, but this isn’t a particularly major concern to me.DISPLAYThe Moto Z utilizes a 5.5-inch QHD AMOLED panel that’s presumably sourced from Samsung (like a lot of other mobile OLED panels).As it is OLED, all of the usual OLED traits are there. Very vivid colors, infinite contrast thanks to deep black levels and great power efficiency.I also found the display pretty good outdoors. It’s not as bright as my old N7, but it does get very bright indeed, making it pretty easy to read in direct sun without having to squint too much.Another bonus is that there’s a color option right in display settings where you can adjust the color gamut. By default, it’s set to “Vivid”, which sacrifices accuracy for more saturation. However, you can go for a “Standard” mode with reduces saturation in order to be more accurate as-per sRGB. It’s not the most accurate display I’ve seen, but it is quite accurate and I’m happy Motorola added an option for it right in the display settings.PERFORMANCEThe Moto Z is a bit of an interesting thing on this front. All Moto Zs (minus the Z Play) use a Qualcomm Snapdragon 820 SoC, which utilizes a quad-core Qualcomm Kyro CPU and an Adreno 530 GPU built on a 14nm process by Samsung. Interestingly, the Droid Edition has its big cores clocked at 2.15GHz while the unlocked versions have it pegged back at 1.82GHz. The small cores stay at 1.6GHz, however.Despite the drop in clockspeed, the Moto Z performs very well. Stutters and actual lag were very rare in occurrence during my time of using it and while the UI may not be as smooth and snappy as that on a Google Pixel, it is definitely one of the faster phones I have used.The Z also utilizes UFS storage, which also results in some of the fastest app-launch speeds I have seen. Apps rarely take more than a second to load up from storage. And RAM management is also very good, with reloaded apps being a rarity.I haven’t had much to complain about in terms of performance, despite the drop in clockspeed on the processor. However, note that the GPU is also underclocked. While this doesn’t result in a noticeable degradation in performance to my eyes, if you’re after every single frame-per-second, unless you’re willing to unlock the bootloader and flash a different kernel, this might not be it for you.But overall, this is a pretty snappy phone. There’s very little performance issues and the drop in clockspeed has almost no effect from my experience.
CAMERAMotorola has never been known for having great cameras, or rather, a good camera. That started to go around with the Moto XPE, but even that had its share of flaws. The Moto Z aims to address some of those……but it’s rather odd.The main sensor is a Sony Exmor IMX214, a 1/3” sensor with a resolution of 4160x3120. If that sounds familiar, it’s the same sensor fitted on many devices dating back to 2014, such as the Nexus 6, HTC One A9 and Moto G 2015. The Z Force, on the other hand, uses a Sony Exmor IMX338, a 1/2.4” sensor with a 21MP resolution, and it’s an upgraded version of the IMX230 found in the Moto XPE. Both phones have OIS and f/1.8 apertures plus laser autofocus (though the Force also has phase-detection autofocus).The camera app is a welcome improvement over past Motorolas. While past Moto camera apps were simple, they were also unfamiliar and sometimes unintuitive as tapping anywhere on the screen takes a photo and one needs to slide to change focus. The Moto Z’s camera is more conventional, utilizing a shutter button to take photos, a button to change modes, sliding gestures to open the gallery or settings menu but the slide-to-focus mechanic remains, although one can now tap to change the focus.I have not used the Z Force, so I am unable to comment on that, but from my time with the camera on the Moto Z, it is a capable camera, but falls a little short from similarly-priced rivals.Daylight performance is typically pretty good, with pleasant amounts of saturation, a large amount of detail and decent dynamic range. White-balance does land a touch warm at times, and it was common for me to dial back the exposure by at least 0.4EV as it does get a little too bright by default, however.When the light goes down, it reveals one key weakness of the Z; low-light performance. It’s not that it’s a bad performer. The wider aperture and OIS does help with aiding for low-light shots that are steady, but the smaller 1/3” sensor does prove to be a bit of a sore point when it comes to noise. Low-light shots also come out pretty bright by default, sometimes resulting in more ISO noise than needed.Handily, the phone does come with a night mode that’s automatically enabled when the surroundings are dark enough or when you adjust the exposure to a certain point. The OIS does help with steadying the shot for a clear night-capture and it does turn out pretty decent, although it still falls short of low-light champs like the Galaxy S7 and Nexus 6P.The camcorder performance is also pretty decent, but also has some flaws. The phone shoots at a 50Mbps bitrate when shooting 4K UHD video, which results in a pretty good looking video, with the option to shoot it in HDR and also enable software stabilization while in UHD. However, at least on mine, the phone has a tendency to drastically shift and hunt for focus, especially while panning. It makes it a little unpleasant to look at, something that I hope is sorted in a future software update.I have not used the selfie camera as I am not the type of guy who takes selfies, but I’ll report back if I do use it a bit.Overall, the camera on the Moto Z is pretty good, which is a revelation compared to past Motos, which had truly horrendous and awful cameras. However, there are still some flaws which puts it just shy of top-tier performers. The Z Force does better in nearly all aspects, though.Samples found here: https://photos.google.com/share/AF1Q...ZFZGtzUWIyejN3SOFTWAREThe Z runs on a very-close-to-stock build of Android 6.0.1 Marshmallow. And it really is close-to-stock. There is almost no form of UI customization and add-ons, being largely like Google’s vision of Android.Since there’s very little change, I won’t go too much into software, although Moto’s additions are still there, alive and well.The main addition is the Moto suite, which provides different gestures and voice commands. I personally have always been fond of the flashlight and camera gestures, and I find that they both work really well, firing up almost consistently in a perfect manner. The voice command now works more like a customized “Okay Google” prompt, but it does work.Other than that, the Moto Z’s software build is pretty much like stock Android. If you’re coming from a Nexus, it should feel very familiar. Though I’ll say that the stock screen density is just too large, especially considering the resolution and size of the display. Android 7.0 Nougat is currently rolling out. Mine hasn’t got it yet, but I’ll post updates below in the thread when it does. Also note that it does not receive security patches in a monthly manner, but does so as part of a package released every few months.BATTERY LIFEOne major con of having such a thin phone is having a smaller battery. The Z has a 2600mAh battery, which is actually pretty darn small for a 5.5-inch device. As such, I expected it to have Galaxy S6-levels of battery life, which is to say “Pretty darn bad”. Turns out, I was sorta wrong….but also sorta right.On my regular usage pattern, I can get 3.5-4 hours of SOT over a 16-18 hour day. On more frugal days, where the phone is in standby most of the time, around 30 hours of total uptime is possible, though SOT goes back at around 2.5-3 hours.Now, that is actually better than I was expecting, but I can’t help but think it could’ve been better had they not made the phone so thin.The included TurboPower charger does charge quickly, though. In 30 minutes, I can top-up half of the phone’s battery, although even plugging it into my non-QC battery bank resulted in decent charging speeds as well.As mentioned before, I am getting an Incipio MotoMod to make it last longer off a wallwart, so I’ll report back when I get it and use it.MOTOMODSIt’s great. No, really. It is.I currently only have the JBL speaker, but it is a pretty good speaker, as it’s very loud and punchy. I had to turn it down a few notches due to how loud it is.Actual operation is also very simple. Just snap and it’s done. Removal is almost as easy as putting it on, though the magnets on this are really strong.Motorola has committed to keeping the MotoMods system going with more support, but considering their past history, I hope they stay true to this one.OTHER STUFF WORTH MENTIONINGFingerprint sensor is lightning fast and usually very accurate, but it is prone to misreads, misfires and sometimes fails to detect my finger at all on the first go. Such moments are rare, however, and the sensor works well in most cases.The single mono-speaker has decent sound quality and is firing in the right direction, but high volumes do sometimes cause it to sound a bit tinny.Despite being in a Style Shell for almost all of its life, the camera glass has one or two faint scratches.It’s nice that it comes with a bumper case, as it can be a bit hard to find suitable cases that don’t hinder the MotoMods.I still miss the dimple, though.Radio performance is good, being able to hold onto a signal well based on carrier coverage and Wi-Fi performance is also quite good. Call quality was also very clear with few issues.FINAL THOUGHTSI personally think the Moto Z is a solid device, and actually does modularity very well. However, there are some flaws in this phone which I think can be deal-breakers for some, especially considering the price of the device, especially in its unlocked form. That said, I don’t think people who opt for a Moto Z are going to be seriously let-down by their purchase, though I do recommend that you go for a Z Force if possible, as you’ll get a bigger battery, more durable display and a better camera.
Is it my absolute favorite of the year? Probably not, but do I like it? Surprisingly, yes.
Good stuff!

title: Is the camera MOD worth the money?

thread.text: Just got my Moto z Droid. Was wondering if the camera MOD was worth the almost $300. Looks interesting but pricey. Thanks for any input.
Look in the moto mod forum. A whole thread on comparisons.

First of all, don't pay $300 for it. It's currently $250 on Amazon, Prime eligible.https://smile.amazon.com/Motorola-Ha...o+z+camera+mod
Is it worth $250? Depends on how much you value getting decent zoom shots. It has some drawbacks, including a lower MP sensor compared to the sensor built into the Z/Z Force/Z Play. At least in early reviews, the focus was slow. The zoom is noisy, which is heard clearly in videos. However, if you have use for zoomed shots, it will handily beat any of the built in sensors for those zoomed shots. There are other threads on here in the Moto Mod section that will give you an idea of photo quality.
Ultimately "worth it" is up to the person opening their wallet, so that's your call.
You can find em' on eBay for under $200

title: Quick Note: The Moto Z has 2 years of unlimited full-res backups to Google Photos

thread.text:
Just in case you guys need to have a refresher;
The Moto Z phones includes the ability to back up full-resolution pictures and 2160p UHD recorded video to Google Photos.
However, unlike the similar promo used for the Google Pixel, this one is limited to 2 years.
It's nice to have, however, and to enable it, you just have to dive into Google Photos' settings on your device and change your backup method from "High Quality" to "Original".

it's likely a method to get people to build up enough files to encourage getting a G Suite subscription with unlimited data, or at least pay a bit extra for storage (I currently pay ~$2/mo for an extra 100GB.)
I have a free terabyte for three years as a Google guide.

title: Android System Killing Battery

thread.text: Been on 7.0 since last week, and all of a sudden starting today Android System is killing my battery. Since unplugging at 3 hours ago, I'm at 44% battery with Android System using 22%. No clue why the voicemail app used 8% either. I've restarted several times and also uninstalled apps that I installed yesterday. Any suggestions?

Android System is a lot of the phone's firmware, so there's not much you can tell by the fact that something in it is using a lot of current. Look on the bottom line of the next graph (tap the graph to get it) to see the lines at the bottom of the page. Mobile network signal should always be green - if it's not, you're on the wrong carrier. (Seriously - that's the first step in choosing a carrier - "Who has the best signal where I need signal?") 8% for voicemail? If you used voicemail, or have it polling (checking every so often), it used 8% of 69%, or 5.52% - and the phone is a heavy user, especially if the mobile network signal is weak.
Welcome to Android Central! Try wiping the cache partition as well: https://motorola-global-portal.custh...p/30,6720,9834

title: OWNERS: What do you LIKE about your Moto Z DROID?

thread.text: What do you LIKE about your Moto Z DROID?

So far just about everything. This device is super slick and fast. I thought my OP3 was slick but the Z is smooth as silk. It's crazy how smooth it is. 
Also I think the build quality is top notch. With the glass screen and all metal design along with the fact it's thin as can be make it a top build IMO. 
Camera is fine for me as well as the video camera. And the Active display is fantastic. 
But to top it all off is the Mods. To be able to snap on and off different accessories makes this device tops for me. Cant wait to see what other mods come along the way.

So far like everything except the style mod that came with the phone. Ugly and slick. However, dropped my Z Force tonight at a restaurant. Hit the concrete floor from table height, style mod popped off but no damage to phone or mod.

I have the force
Battery life is outstanding- with the battery mod I know I can go all day without a charger !!!
It is very fluid and fast, big step up from my LG G4
Screen is excellent, and it is the right size for me
Plus, I am impressing the heck out of my customers on appointments, when I swap mods, they have never heard of this phone
If you are on the fence, I am telling you, jump right on over that fence and get one

replies.text: With the battery mod on my Z Force, I could easily do 48 hours so long as I'm not playing Pokemon all day and night.

thread.text:
So I have used the phone now for over a week now since its release. I'm still amazed by the size. I know many people got the Force for the battery , screen, and camera but I got the Z for the size. The screen is amazing. I dont take many photos but the fee I have done came out fine for me. Battery has been good also. 
I am more impressed by the size of the phone. The build is fantastic feels premium and solid. I really enjoy holding it The first device in a while I have used without a case. Build is excellent.

replies.text:
They are very thin which I like, but does the 6+ inch length work for you? For example, how large does it feel in your pocket? The size has always been a bit of a concern for me as I try to balance form with function. 
Cheers!

thread.text: I have had my Z (not force) for week now and I have to say I LOVE it. It is so freaking thin and light. I have been using it without the shell and plan just use it naked. The camera hump doesn't bother me. Also, so buttery smooth and fast. For example, the flashlight chop is so much fast/smoother than my Pure X which I loved. Also, I don't have a problem with battery life, it is about the same as the Pure X. I bought a car charger and it seems turbo charge is faster than the X. I was going to buy the battery mod but I really don't think I will need it. Best phone I have ever had and I understand the negatives expressed but I just love the thinness. It is a joy to carry and hold.

I like the thinness. The speaker is ok and the USB c is good. I hate that since I'm a power user I have to use a mod to get really good battery life. Makes the phone huge even though the phone is soo thin to begin with. 
I don't know I'm starting to realize my cons are more plentiful than my pros. Maybe I'm just trying to convince myself to drop $1k on a note 7.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: Or exchange for a Z Force...

Despite having a large QHD screen and only a 2600mah battery I am actually getting 4-5 hours SOT which matches my use with other devices. I'm quite impressed by Motorola's optimization to manage such good battery life in such a thin body. It's not the battery beast like I got out of my moto x play, but it's ok. It is on par with my HTC 10, which I was also impressed with as far as battery life goes. 
Me personally I have barely used the battery mod (thought it's handy to have if I need it). I either get through the day without a mod, or I use the fast charger for half an hour in the middle of the day to get me through the night with a lot of juice still left

thread.text: I've seen several people complain about the size of the phone when they use the battery mod. I feel that I'd rather deal with the size than to have to find an outlet and hope I remembered my charger. And then have to wait 30 minutes by the outlet. The mod is on when I leave the house and will get me through a full day with heavy use and no plugging it in. If I worked in an office near an outlet at all times, I might feel different. But I love the battery mod.
The battery life is still amazing.

Love- size and thinness...very lightweight. Battery has been great for me..it charges so fast anyway if you did need to bump charge midday it wouldn't take long ...Plus there's always the mods. It's fast, no lag or stuttering. The front facing fingerprint sensor (which works very well and fast) and the ability to also turn off the screen via that, very ergonomic. Build quality is top notch. What I'd change- faster focus on the camera and overall better camera, I can live with this for now....this would include getting rid of the camera hump. More cases! Manufacturers need to step up....Verizon was smart and made a bumper only case to use with the mods but it's somewhat awkward....great idea and meh on implementing.. I will keep thinking but that's my list for now..I was a note 7 refugee so size wise it's no problem for me

I paid off a DT2 to get the Z, and by far the best thing about this phone is the battery life. With the Tumi mod I got two full days out of the phone over Thanksgiving weekend with minimal wireless charging in the car.

(1) thin, solid design is very high-end

title: How to turn off sensors? [Moto Display Issues]

thread.text:
I've been a Moto Z user for several weeks now, at first the Moto Display was a charm letting me check notifications and the usual "What time is it?" at a glance. However after a week it got annoying than the Moto Display would activate nearly all the time.
I work in an office and have the phone sitting on my desk, turns out that every time I moved my arm or lean in Moto Display will show. So I decided to disable the Moto Display in Moto App --> Actions. But now, the Moto Display keeps turning on whenever there is a small vibration/movement in the table, or while driving when I pass over a bumper or uneven streets. 
Is there a way to disable it altogether? Truth is, I'm more worried over the battery consumption than the occasional Moto Display turning on (1 or 2 times an hour, it's a noisy office with lots of movement). Plus it bothers me that the phone won't act as I thought it would.

It doesn't really affect battery life at all but you can turn it off. Just go into the moto app on your phone and the display and then turn it off. Notifications on the screen will be turned off. Good luck!

Thanks a lot! I thought disabling the "Approach for Moto Display" under "Actions" would do it. 
Turning off the Display was what I was looking for.

Example 2:

title: how are you liking the Z?

thread.text: Now that some people have had it for awhile how is everything? Battery life, call quality ,just everything in general?

I've had mine for 2 weeks already.
So far, I am quite happy with it. Performance was snappy and on-point almost every time, battery life was lean but it did manage to last me through the day (although it did require me to adjust my usage pattern on the fly) and Motorola radios are pretty strong in my experience, so I was able to get a decent signal with solid call quality across different countries and carriers. The camera, though, is good but for $699, isn't quite in the level of "great", where the Galaxy S7, iPhone 7, Pixel and other phones live.
The interesting thing is that mine is the unlocked model, which works on AT&T, T-Mobile and other GSM networks. Compared to the Verizon-exclusive Z Droid Edition, the processor is clocked sliightly lower at 1.82GHz, compared to 2.15GHz on the Droid and supports up to Category 6 LTE, compared to Category 9 LTE on the Droid.

replies.text:
I bought an unlocked Moto Z from clove. I didn't know the processor was clocked lower. Despite this the Z feels a lot smoother than the HTC 10. On one hand I think the Z price is good. It's better performance than more expensive phones, great software experience, great build. But then again you can get the Play for a fair bit cheaper which still has good performance and a lot better battery life. Regardless I feel the Z matches/out performs more expensive phones, so I'm satisfied with the price. 
I just got a mi max to use as a small tablet/back up device. It's fine for a cheap tablet/back up phone, but it's certainly made me appreciate how well Motorola do software! I love that the UI is near stock, doesn't have a heap of gimmicky features and bloat, but has a few additions on top of stock that I actually use! Most skinned phones I'll try out the new features, think they are cool, then forget about them and never use again.
